contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox software | logo = | developer = [[GNU Project]], Henrik Sandklef | latest release version = 3.15 | latest release date = {{release date and age|2012|12|22}}<ref name="news">{{cite mailing list |last= Sandklef |first=Henrik |title=GNU Xnee 3.15 ('Shankar') released |publisher=info-gnu |date=2012-12-22 |url=http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/info-gnu/2012-12/msg00012.html |accessdate=2012-12-24}}</ref> | operating system = [[X11]] | genre = [[X11]] [[Software testing|Test]] | license = [[GNU General Public License]] | website = http://www.sandklef.com/xnee }} '''GNU Xnee''' is a suite of programs that can record, replay and distribute user actions under the [[X11]] environment. It can be used for testing and demonstrating X11 applications.<ref name="LJ">{{cite journal |url=http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/6660 |title=Testing Applications with Xnee |author=Henrik Sandklef |date=January 1, 2004 |journal=[[Linux Journal]] |accessdate=August 14, 2009}}</ref> Within X11 each user input (mouse click or key press) is an [[X Window System]] event. Xnee records these events into a file. Later Xnee is used to play the events back from the file and into an X Window System just as though the user were operating the system.<ref name="Jerry yin Hom">{{cite web |url=http://www.research.rutgers.edu/~jhom/pubs/thesis.pdf |title=An Execution Context Optimization Framework for Disk Energy |author=Jerry yin Hom |date=May, 2008 |format=pdf |pages=56–57 |accessdate=August 14, 2009}}</ref> Xnee can also be used to play or ''distribute'' user input events to two or more machines in parallel.<ref name="LJ"/> As the target X Window application sees what appears to be physical user input it has resulted in Xnee being dubbed “''Xnee is Not an Event Emulator''.”<ref name="Jerry yin Hom"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://itupw056.itu.chalmers.se/xnee/doc/xnee.html#SEC118 |title=Xnee FAQ |publisher=[[Free Software Foundation]] |accessdate=August 14, 2009}}</ref> As Xnee is [[free software]], it can be modified to handle special tasks. For example, inserting time stamps as part of the playback.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~gghartma/final-report.pdf |title=Methods for Recognizing Service Quiescence |author=Gregory Hartman |coauthors=Jack Lin; Michael Merideth |date=December 12, 2002 |format=pdf |pages=7–8 |accessdate=August 14, 2009}}</ref> ==See also== * [[xdotool]] * [[xautomation]] ==External links== * [http://www.sandklef.com/xnee/ Official site] * [http://search.cpan.org/~mkoderer/X11-GUITest-record-0.11/lib/X11/GUITest/record.pm X11::GUITest::record] - Perl implementation of the X11 record extension * [http://sourceforge.net/projects/x11guitest X11::GUITest] - X11 Recording / Playbook using Perl script ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Portal|Free software}} [[Category:Personal computer automation software]] [[Category:X Window System]] [[Category:GNU Project software|Xnee]] {{Software-stub}}
